revision.text:
{{about|the particle accelerator at the Louvre|the French female name, derived from the Greek goddess name|Agla%C3%A9}} '''Accélérateur Grand Louvre d'analyse élémentaire (AGLAE)''' is a [[particle accelerator]] housed by the [[Center for Research and Restoration of Museums of France]] in the [[Louvre]] museum in [[Paris]], [[France]]. <ref name="2015-05-14_Symetry">[http://www.symmetrymagazine.org/article/may-2015/the-accelerator-in-the-louvre The accelerator in the Louvre -- The Accélérateur Grand Louvre d'analyse élémentaire solves ancient mysteries with powerful particle beams.], Glenn Roberts Jr. and Kelen Tuttle, Summetry Magazine, 14 May 2015, accessed 7 July 2015</ref>
==Details== AGLAE is a [[Pelletron]] 2[[MeV]] [[electrostatic accelerator]] built by an American company, the [[National Electrostatics Corporation]], and has two sources: * a [[Duoplasmatron]]+ source that can produce hydrogen ions (protons), and * an [[Alpha source]] that can produce Helium ions (two protons and two [[neutron]]s bound together into a particle identical to a [[helium]] nucleus). This produces protons with an energy up to 4 MeV and alphas up to 6 MeV.<ref name="C2RMF">[http://c2rmf.fr/analyser/un-laboratoire-de-haute-technologie-pour-les-collections-des-musees/aglae AGLAE], Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musees de France (C2RMF), accessed 7 July 2015</ref>
AGLAE was installed starting in 1987 and inaugurated in 1989.<ref name="C2RMF" /> AGLAE is sited some 15m below the [[Louvre Pyramid|glass pyramid at the Louvre]].
==Use== AGLAE generates [[proton]]s and [[Alpha particle]]s that are emitted outside the accelerator itself, enabling items of virtually any size or type to be examined. The particles, and their collision products, are detected to analyse the composition of the cultural items in the path of the particle beams. The techniques used at AGLAE include particle-induced [[X-ray]] and [[gamma-ray]] emission spectrometries.<ref name="2015-05-14_Symetry" />
The data is used to determine the atomic constituents of the cultural items, including trace elements.<ref name="2015-05-14_Symetry" />
===Detectors=== AGLAE implements derived methods of analysis with two ion beams:<ref name="C2RMF" /> * emission induced X-charged particles (PIXE) * [[Ernest Rutherford|Rutherford]] backscattering spectrometry (RBS) * analysis by nuclear reactions (NRA), a variant is called GAUGE (gamma-induced charged particle emission) * elastic recoil detection analysis (ERDA) * a spectrometer to record the ionoluminescence on the extracted beam line (IBIL)
===Upgrade=== AGLAE particle analysis techniques are limited in that they are not very effective for studying paintings because of a slight risk of damage. An upgrade (NEW AGLAE, using an ANR-10-EQPX-22<ref name="C2RMF" />) in progress in 2015 aims to produce a lower-power beam that will allow more sensitive detectors to overcome this issue, and allow 24-hour operation of the facility.<ref name="2015-05-14_Symetry" />
==Directors== Dr [[Claire Pacheco]] - 2011-current<ref name="2015-05-14_Symetry" />
==References== {{commons category}} {{reflist}}
{{coord|48.8610|N|2.3316|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:AGLAE}} [[Category:Particle accelerators]] [[Category:Louvre]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox document |document_name= Azawadi Declaration of Independence |image=MNLA flag.svg |image_width=175px |image_caption=MNLA's adopted flag for their [[Azawad|Independent State of Azawad]]. |date_created= 6 April 2012 |date_ratified= |location_of_document= [[Gao]] |writer=[[National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad]] |signers= Secretary General
[[Bilal Ag Acherif]] |purpose= Independence of the [[Azawad]] from [[Mali]] |url= [[s:Azawad Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]] }} On 6 April 2012, the [[National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad]] (French acronym: MNLA) unilaterally declared [[Azawad]] independent from the [[Republic of Mali]] in the wake of a [[Tuareg rebellion (2012)|rebellion]] which was preceded by a string of other [[Tuareg rebellions (disambiguation)|Tuareg rebellions]]. It is called the '''Independent State of Azawad'''. ==History== Following the return of several hundreds of soldiers after the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] in 2011 and the formation of the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad,{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/tuareg-rebels-attack-6th-town-mali-182107726.html |title=Tuareg rebels attack 6th town in Mali |date=31 January 2012 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=Yahoo News |last=Vogl |first=Martin |accessdate=17 October 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTuLUMke?url=http://news.yahoo.com/tuareg-rebels-attack-6th-town-mali-182107726.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} an insurgency commenced on 17 January 2012 with an attack in the [[Kidal Region]], near the border with [[Algeria]]. Following the [[2012 Malian coup d'état|March coup d'état]], the rebels made further inroads to capture the three biggest cities of [[Kidal]], [[Gao]] and [[Timbuktu]] in three days, respectively. At this point, other factions joined the fighting, including the [[Islamist]] [[Ansar Dine]] and the [[Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa]]. Despite reports of Ansar Dine taking control of most of what was initially captured by or with the help of the MNLA, the group established their writ over large swathes of the territory.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/04/20124644412359539.html |title=Tuaregs claim 'independence' from Mali |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTuUrtbo?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/04/20124644412359539.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The Tuareg peoples had also long complained of marginalisation within Mali.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/apr/06/mali-tuareg-rebels-declare-independence?newsfeed=true |title=Mali's Tuareg rebels declare independence |publisher=The Guardian |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTuc0TTk?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/apr/06/mali-tuareg-rebels-declare-independence?newsfeed=true |archivedate=17 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ==Declaration of Independence== The Secretary-General of the MNLA, [[Bilal ag Acherif]], signed the declaration in Gao, the site of the largest Malian military outpost in the north, on 6 April 2012. It was announced by Moussa ag Attaher on ''[[France 24]]''. The declaration was issued in [[French language|French]] on behalf of the "voice of the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad" and in consultation with the Executive Committee, the Revolutionary Council, the Consultative Council, the State-Major of the Army of Liberation and the regional offices.{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/06/205763.html |title=Tuareg rebels declare the independence of Azawad, north of Mali |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTuuxrYR?url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/06/205763.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} It also cited as reasoning [[History of Mali|France's unilateral attachment of the region to Mali]] despite an appeal to French President [[Charles de Gaulle]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/africa/6706498/Mali-rebels-declare-independence |title=Mali rebels declare independence – africa – world |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTv0A7sK?url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/africa/6706498/Mali-rebels-declare-independence |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The document concluded by adding that the new state declared by the MNLA would recognise international state borders, despite having split the traditional [[Azawagh]] over several modern-day states; absolute accordance with the [[United Nations Charter]]; and a commitment by the MNLA to establish the "conditions for a durable peace" and create state institutions in accordance with a [[Constitution of Azawad|democratic constitution]]. Before "irrevocably" acclaiming the Independent State of Azawad, the document called on the Executive Committee, who would run the country in the interim period, to invite the [[international community]] to immediately recognise the new state in the interests of "justice and peace".{{cite web|url=http://www.mnlamov.net/component/content/article/169-declaration-dindependance-de-lazawad.html |title=Déclaration D’Indépendance De L'Azawad |language=French |publisher=Mouvement National de libération de l'Azawad |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTul59wU?url=http://www.mnlamov.net/component/content/article/169-declaration-dindependance-de-lazawad.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} ===Reactions=== The day before the declaration, the Foreign Ministry of [[Algeria]] said that an armed faction raided the Algerian consulate in the northeast kidnapping the consul and six staff members. Though Attaher called it "deplorable", he said the MNLA went along with the action in order not to result in deaths. The ''[[Agence France Press|AFP]]'' also quoted a Malian military source as saying that to the best of Malian Army's intelligence "the MNLA is in charge of nothing at the moment... it is Iyad [[[Iyad ag Ghaly|Ag Ghaly]]] who is the strongest and he is with AQIM". His [[Ansar Dine]] said that it was "against rebellions. We are against independence. We are against revolutions not in the name of Islam."{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20120406-world-rejects-tuareg-independence-declaration-north-mali-rebel-international-community-azawad |title=Global powers dismiss Tuaregs’ declared independence |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=8 April 2012 |agency=Agence France-Presse |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTv88t4H?url=http://www.france24.com/en/20120406-world-rejects-tuareg-independence-declaration-north-mali-rebel-international-community-azawad |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Some of the MLNA's leadership were also said to have been surprised by the declaration. Europe-based Hama Ag Sid'Ahmed, one of the spokesmen of the MNLA and the head of external relations, said: "I think it's premature — premature to speak of this right now, without a consultation and an understanding with some of the actors that are very active on the local level, and with which we need to work, and we need to find common objectives, common strategies."{{cite news |author=Callimachi, Rukmini |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2111370,00.html#ixzz1riyrZa4x |title=Mali's Tuareg Rebels Declare Independence |work=Time |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=11 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTvEaFmf?url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2111370,00.html#ixzz1riyrZa4x |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} '''Supranational bodies''' *[[African Union]]: The AU rejected the UDI as "null and of no value whatsoever" and appealed to the rest of the world to ignore it.{{cite news|last=Felix |first=Bate |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/04/06/uk-mali-idUKBRE83503Y20120406 |title=Mali rebels declare independent 'Azawad' |publisher=Reuters |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTvIiWw5?url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/04/06/uk-mali-idUKBRE83503Y20120406 |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The AU's commission chairperson [[Jean Ping]]'s office issued a statement that read he "calls on the international community as a whole to fully support this principled position of Africa". *[[Economic Community of West African States]]: ECOWAS declared they would "take all necessary measures, including the use of force, to ensure the territorial integrity" of Mali.{{cite news|author=Fessy, Thomas |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17640223 |title=Mali Tuareg rebels' call on independence rejected |publisher=BBC News |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=8 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTvTYrWp?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17640223 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ECOWAS announced preparations for a 3,000 personnel intervention force to contain the rebels and protect the [[constitution of Mali]].{{cite web|last=Felix |first=Bate |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/06/us-mali-idUSBRE83507L20120406 |title=AU, US reject Mali rebels' independence declaration |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=17 October 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTva7FTG?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/06/us-mali-idUSBRE83507L20120406 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} *{{flag|European Union}}: The spokeswoman for the Representative for Foreign Affairs, [[Catherine Ashton]], said that the EU respected Mali's territorial integrity. Richard Zinc, EU representative in Bamako, said that it was "out of question" that the EU would accept the declaration.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article3287371.ece |title=Mali's Tuareg rebels declare independence |author=Callimachi, Rukmini |work=The Hindu |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012 |agency=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTtyUjh4?url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article3287371.ece |archivedate=17 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} '''States''' *{{flag|Algeria}}: Prime Minister [[Ahmed Ouyahia]] said Azawad's northern neighbour country would never "accept questioning Mali's territorial integrity". However, he also rejected foreign intervention and called for a solution through dialogue.{{cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/38627/World/International/Algeria-rules-out-Mali-split,-foreign-intervention.aspx |title=Algeria rules out Mali split, foreign intervention: Report |agency=Agence France-Presse |publisher=english.ahram.org.eg |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTvrYK7p?url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/38627/World/International/Algeria-rules-out-Mali-split,-foreign-intervention.aspx |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} *{{flag|Canada}}: Chris Day, an aide to Foreign Minister [[John Baird (Canadian politician)|John Baird]], stated that Canada's position on Azawad's independence: "We’re absolutely not recognising this declaration. We are closely monitoring events on the ground."{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/apnewsbreak-malis-coup-leader-return-power-215323797.html |title=Mali's coup leader to return power |agency=Associated Press |publisher=The Globe and Mail |author=Callimachi, Rukmini |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTw0et3P?url=http://news.yahoo.com/apnewsbreak-malis-coup-leader-return-power-215323797.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} *{{flag|France}}: Defence Minister [[Gérard Longuet]] reacted by saying: "A unilateral declaration of independence which is not recognised by African states would not have any meaning for us." Foreign ministry spokesman Bernard Valero said the declaration was "null and void". He affirmed France's commitment to the "territorial integrity of Mali".{{cite web|url=http://pmnewsnigeria.com/2012/04/06/malian-group-eu-france-denounce-independence-proclamation/ |title=Malian Group, EU, France Denounce Independence Proclamation |publisher=P.M. News |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=6 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTwAId0u?url=http://pmnewsnigeria.com/2012/04/06/malian-group-eu-france-denounce-independence-proclamation/ |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On the other hand, Valero admitted that "the demands of the northern Tuareg population are old and for too long had not received adequate and necessary responses". France, however, also indicated it would offer military assistance to the ECOWAS force aimed at stabilising Mali and containing the rebels. *{{flag|Russia}}: In a statement the same day as the declaration, the presidential special envoy to Africa [[Mikhail Margelov]] rejected the formation of the state. "There are virtually no chances, this is undoubted, for [the] legitimization of a Tuareg state." "[The Sahelian countries, the ECOWAS, and the AU] do not need it. We stand unequivocally for the territorial integrity and restoration of the constitutional order in Mali."{{cite news|url=http://english.cri.cn/6966/2012/04/06/191s691857.htm |title=Russia: No Chance to Recognize Azawad Independence |agency=Xinhua |publisher=CRI English |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=7 April 2012 |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTwCtigt?url=http://english.cri.cn/6966/2012/04/06/191s691857.htm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} *{{flag|United States}}: Patrick Ventrell, a spokesman of the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] stated: "We reject the MNLA's statement of independence and reiterate our call for the territorial integrity of Mali." The State Department also later expressed concern that the separation would "only exacerbate the grave problems challenging the Malian state".{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/05/27/world/africa/mali-rebel-groups/index.html |title=Mali rebel groups join forces, vowing an Islamic state |author=Katarina Höije |date=27 May 2012 |publisher=CNN |archivedate=17 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTwRWbSQ?url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/05/27/world/africa/mali-rebel-groups/index.html |accessdate=17 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} '''Academia''' Alessandra Giuffrida of the African Studies Department at the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] said:
[The MNLA] is taking advantage of a new situation:the lack of a constitutional government and power vacuum in Bamako after the coup. This is a new fact which has never occurred before in the history of the Tuareg in Mali. According to international law experts, this actually gives the Tuareg some ground to fight legally for the independence of their state. [The international reactions reflect that] there are economic interests in maintaining the status quo in the north of the country after the discovery of mineral resources.{{cite quote|date=February 2018}}
==See also== {{portal|Africa}} * [[Declaration of independence]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.webcitation.org/6BTul59wU?url=http://www.mnlamov.net/component/content/article/169-declaration-dindependance-de-lazawad.html Full original text of declaration] {{fr icon}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Declaration of independence (Azawad)}} [[Category:History of Azawad]] [[Category:Declarations of independence|Azawad, declaration of independence]] [[Category:2012 in international relations]] [[Category:2012 in Mali]] [[Category:Northern Mali conflict]] [[Category:April 2012 events]] [[Category:2012 documents]]

Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Cedid Atlas Title Page.jpg|thumb|right|Title Page of the ''Cedid Atlas'' (also known as ''Cedid Atlas Tercümesi'')]]
'''''Cedid Atlas''''' (or ''Atlas-ı Cedid'') is the first translation of the [[atlas]] in the [[Muslim world]], printed and published in 1803 in [[Constantinople]], then the capital of the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref name="hgk">[http://www.hgk.msb.gov.tr/ustbanner/turk/ilkatlas.htm First Printed Atlas in the Muslim World] {{tr icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.antiquemapsandprintsblog.com/antique-maps/ Antique Maps - Timeline of Cartography]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofinformation.com/expanded.php?id=510|title=The First World Atlas Printed by Muslims (April 1803 – March 1804)|publisher=}}</ref> The full title name of the atlas reads as '''''Cedid Atlas Tercümesi''''' (meaning, literally, ''"A Translation of a New Atlas"'') and in most libraries outside Turkey, it is recorded and referenced accordingly.
Although manuscripts and hand-drawn maps were widely available throughout the [[Muslim world]], the massive printing of books started only in 1729 by [[Ibrahim Muteferrika]] and the ''Cedid Atlas'' could only be published in 1803 by Müderris Abdurrahman Efendi in a style based on European sources.<ref name="hgk" />
The ''Cedid Atlas'' includes a monochrome celestial chart and 24 hand-coloured copper engraved maps <ref name=Beydilli>Beydilli(1995) {{tr icon}}</ref> of various parts of the world; the celestial chart and maps measure at least (53 cm by 72 cm) and all the maps are actually adaptations <ref name="LOC">{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/9811/atlas.html|title=Artifacts from the 'New Order' (November 1998) - Library of Congress Information Bulletin|publisher=}}</ref> of [[William Faden]]'s <ref>[http://www.geographicus.com/mm5/merchant.mvc?Screen=CAD&Product_Code=faden William Faden's Biography]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> ''General Atlas''. The maps are preceded by a (1+79) page-long treatise of geography, "Ucalet-ül Coğrafiye" by Mahmud Raif Efendi <ref>[http://dergiler.ankara.edu.tr/dergiler/19/1151/13525.pdf Mahmud Raif Efendi As The Chief Secretary of Yusuf Agah Efendi, The First Permanent Ottoman-Turkish Ambassador to London (1793-1797)]</ref><ref>[http://www.tarihbilinci.com/forum/devlet-adamlari-223/mahmud-raif-efendi-15164/ Mahmud Raif Efendi's Ucalet-ül Coğrafiye] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120628010333/http://www.tarihbilinci.com/forum/devlet-adamlari-223/mahmud-raif-efendi-15164/# |date=2012-06-28 }} {{tr icon}}</ref> and a title page. The "Ucalet-ül Coğrafiye" of Mahmud Raif Efendi was printed one year later, in 1804, and bound together with the atlas.<ref name=TB>[http://www.tarihbilinci.com/forum/devlet-adamlari-223/mahmud-raif-efendi-15164/ Ottoman Statesmen: Mahmud Raif Efendi] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120628010333/http://www.tarihbilinci.com/forum/devlet-adamlari-223/mahmud-raif-efendi-15164/# |date=2012-06-28 }} {{tr icon}}</ref>
From a point of view of art, the atlas is notable for the color of the maps as well as the beauty of the script on the maps.<ref name="NJ">{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/news/times/regional/index.ssf?/base/news-19/127148311969290.xml&coll=5|title=In this map, it's still Constantinople|publisher=}}</ref>
The ''Cedid Atlas'' was published in parallel with the developments of the [[Ottoman Empire]]'s [[Nizam-ı Cedid]], the "New-Order" or the "New System" ("Cedid" means "new" and "Nizam" means "system", "regime", or "order") and its title-name reflects this clearly. The atlas was new in terms of cartographical knowledge and well suited to the new system which tried to introduce new institutions into the [[Ottoman Empire]] while trying to replace existing ones with contemporary counterparts from the [[West]]. Introduced by the ruling [[padishah]] (the [[sultan]]) of the [[Ottoman Empire]], [[Selim III]], the "New-Order" included a series of reforms which mainly modernized and changed the structure of the then existing [[Ottoman army]] and changed the administrative structure of the Empire. It was an effort to catch up with technical, military, economic, and administrative achievements of the [[West]] against which the [[Ottoman Empire]] was losing grounds since the 17th century. New military and engineering schools were established and governmental units related with the foreign relations and affairs were re-organized to align with the new system. For these schools, governmental units, and the wholly re-organized army reformed according to the European practice, a new understanding and applications of geography of the standards of the West were necessary and the ''Cedid Atlas'' was translated and printed for this purpose.
Only 50 copies of this atlas (measuring 36 cm x 53 cm) were printed at the press. A copy was presented to [[Selim III]]; several copies were also presented to the high-ranking officials of the Empire, some were reserved for the library of Muhendishane (military engineering school of the time), and the remaining were reserved for sale. However, during the "Alemdar Vakası", an uprising of the [[janissaries]] in Constantinople during November 15–18, 1808,<ref name=Kinross431-434>Kinross(1977), pp 431-434.</ref> a fire at the warehouse of the press destroyed an unknown (unaccounted) number of the copies reserved for sale.<ref name="Uskudar">[http://www.uskudar.bel.tr/tr-TR/haberler/Sayfalar/Haber.aspx?hid=2355 Municipality of Usküdar-Istanbul] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130418145114/http://www.uskudar.bel.tr/tr-TR/haberler/Sayfalar/Haber.aspx?hid=2355 |date=2013-04-18 }} {{tr icon}}</ref> Based on several estimates and accounting for the single maps (torn-out from bound volumes of the atlas) sold or being sold worldwide, it is believed that a maximum of 20 complete examples could be present in libraries or in private collections <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swaen.com/antique-map-of.php?id=12429|title=RAIF EFENDI - Guyana, Surinam, Amapa.|author=Antique maps Paulus Swaen Auction Galleries|publisher=}}</ref> whereas some sources suggest that there exist only 10 complete and intact copies in the world.<ref name="LOC" /><ref name="Uskudar" /><ref name="Princeton">[http://blogs.princeton.edu/rarebooks/2010/05/_princeton_university_librarys.html Newly acquired: Cedid Atlas Tercümesi (Istanbul, 1803)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320090137/http://blogs.princeton.edu/rarebooks/2010/05/_princeton_university_librarys.html |date=March 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="JCB">{{cite web|url=http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/I%20found%20it%20JCB/apr11.html|publisher=The John Carter Brown Library|title=The New Great Atlas: Istanbul, 1803-1804 |author=Allison Rich|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606011702/http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/I%20found%20it%20JCB/apr11.html|archive-date=2012-06-06}}</ref> As such, it's one of the rarest printed atlases of historical value.<ref name="LOC" /><ref name="Uskudar" /><ref name="Princeton" /><ref name="JCB" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/3413648|title=[World map in Mercator's projection] [cartographic material] - National Library of Australia|publisher=}}</ref>
==Other names== A few sources outside [[Turkey]] and the [[Muslim world]] also refer to this atlas as the '''''New Great Atlas'''''.<ref name="JCB" /> In Turkey, since the printing press of the book was located in the historical [[Üsküdar]] (Scutari) region (now a municipality) of [[Istanbul]], the atlas sometimes is referred to as the '''''Üsküdar Atlası'''''.<ref name="Uskudar" />
==Existing copies== These are the only 12 complete copies known to exist in the world:
# Turkey - Topkapı Sarayı ([[Topkapı Palace]]) - 1 copy - Complete # Turkey - Library of the [[Istanbul Technical University]] (İstanbul Teknik Üniversitesi, formerly known as ""Engineering School (Mühendislik Mektebi")) - 2 copies - Complete (''presence of copies are not confirmed'') # Turkey - Library of the [[Boğaziçi University]] (Boğaziçi Üniversitesi, formerly known as [[Robert College]]) - 3 copies - Complete (''presence of only 1 copy is confirmed'') # Turkey - Municipality of [[Üsküdar]](Üsküdar Belediyesi) - 1 copy - Complete # U.S.A. - [[Library of Congress]] - 1 copy - Complete # U.S.A. - [[Princeton University Library]] - 1 copy - Complete # Netherlands - [[Leiden University Library]] - 1 copy - Complete # United Arab Emirates - Antiquarian bookseller; [https://www.abebooks.com/eqtna-rare-books-manuscripts-ras-khaimah/54391949/sf Eqtna for Rare Books]. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abebooks.com/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=22380151623&searchurl=bi=0&ds=30&sortby=17&tn=cedid&vci=54391949&cm_sp=snippet-_-srp1-_-title1|title=Cedid Atlas Tercumesi [ New Atlas, translated ] by Effendi, Mahmoud Raif: Uksudar ( Istanbul) Tabhane-i Humayun press Hardcover, 1st Edition - EQTNA (Rare Books & Manuscripts)|website=www.abebooks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref>The copy was displayed for sale at the [http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/culture/rare-atlas-worth-dh550-500-at-sharjah-fair-1.1923787 Sharjah Book Fair 2016].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/culture/rare-atlas-worth-dh550-500-at-sharjah-fair-1.1923787|title=Rare ‘Arabian Nights’ book in Arabic at the Sharjah book fair|last=|first=|date=|website=The Gulf Today|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-02-23}}</ref> - 1 copy - Complete # Swann Auction Galleries, New York - 1 complete copy sold on 26 May 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://catalogue.swanngalleries.com/asp/fullCatalogue.asp?salelot=2417+++++199+&refno=++718984&saletype=|title=Full Details for Lot 199|website=catalogue.swanngalleries.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-08}}</ref>
(Contrary to sources, on-line library search at the library of [[Boğaziçi University]] shows only 1 copy according to the records, and an on-line search at the library of the [[Istanbul Technical University]] shows no copies according to records. [[WorldCat]] union catalogue search of all the libraries confirms this result. Accordingly, there are only 10 complete and intact copies confirmed to exist in the world.)
These are the incomplete copies known to exist in the world: # U.S.A. - [[John Carter Brown Library]] ([[Brown University]]) - 1 copy (missing 2 maps) # U.S.A. - [[Newberry Library]] - 1 copy (missing 1 map and also 1 available map is from another copy) # Turkey - Yapı Kredi Sermet Çifter Araştırma Kütüphanesi - 1 copy (missing several maps) # Turkey - Bursa İnebey Kütüphanesi - 1 copy (missing several maps) # Norway - Nasjonalbiblioteket ([[National Library of Norway]]) - 1 copy (missing 2 maps) <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/01/15/463209833/norways-national-library-discovers-rare-atlas-with-a-little-help-from-reddit|title=Norway's National Library Discovers Rare Atlas — With A Little Help From Reddit|date=15 January 2016|work=NPR.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2016/01/14/how-a-karma-seeking-redditor-uncovered-one-of-the-worlds-rarest-atlases/|title=How a karma-seeking Redditor uncovered one of the world’s rarest atlases|author=AbOhlheiser|date=14 January 2016|work=Washington Post}}</ref> # Sweden - Kungliga Biblioteket (Royal Library of Sweden) - 1 copy (missing the title page) <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://goran.baarnhielm.net/Islam/eng/Cedid_Atlas.htm|title=Utställningen|website=goran.baarnhielm.net|access-date=2017-02-08}}</ref> # Austria - Antikvariat InLibris, Vienna - 1 copy (Missing the celestial chart).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zvab.com/servlet/SearchResults?an=Mahmoud&tn=Cedid+Atlas+Terc%25FCmesi&cm_sp=mbc-_-SRP-_-all|title=Cedid Atlas Terc%FCmesi von Mahmoud - ZVAB|website=www.zvab.com|language=de__ZVAB|access-date=2017-02-08}}</ref>
The following libraries possess very limited portions of the atlas :
# [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] owns the initial (1+79) page-long geographical treatise "Ucalet-ül Coğrafiye" and one map only, title page and the remaining maps of the atlas are missing. # [[National Library of Australia]] owns only two maps of the atlas with all the rest missing.
Occasionally, single maps of the Cedid Atlas are presented for sale by on-line book sellers or auctioneers.
==Maps in the ''Cedid Atlas''== In addition to the (53 cm x 72 cm) monochrome celestial map, there are 24 coloured maps in the atlas; some of them are larger than (53 cm x 72 cm). In order of appearance, these maps show:
# Eastern Hemisphere and Western Hemisphere # South Pole and North Pole # The World # Europe (including Iceland) # Anatolia, Black Sea, Aegean Sea, Balkan Peninsula, (heel of) Italy, Iraq/Syria/Lebanon/Jordan/Palestine/Cyprus/Crete (in the south) # Adriatic Coast, Italy, Southern France, Iberian Peninsula, Libya/Tunis/Algeria (in the south) # Anatolia (the) Black Sea, Crimea, Southern Ukraine, (north of) Balkan Peninsula to Hungary # Western Anatolia, Aegean Sea, Crete (in the south), Greece # England (and Wales) # Scotland and Scottish Islands # The Low Countries : Hanau, Luxembourg, Brabant, Flanders, Northern France # France (at the time of the monarchy) # The English Channel and the Channel Islands, Western France Coast # France (at the time of the republic) # Germany (from Brandenburg to Braunschweig) # Poland, Prussia, Lithuania (to the north) # Continent of Asia # Azerbaijan, Armenia, Western Iran, Iraq/Syria/Lebanon/Jordan/Palestine/Cyprus (in the south), Anatolia # Continent of Africa # River Nile in Egypt in detail (including the Nile Delta) # Continents of America (North, Central, South) and (part of) Pacific Ocean # Eastern North America # Central/South America (Guyana) Coast # The Lesser Antilles (including) Puerto Rico, Trinidad, Tobago
==Paper used for the maps in the ''Cedid Atlas''== The watermark of the papers on which the maps were printed were examined. While some [[Princeton University]] professors believe the papers are Russian-made, John Delaney, the historical maps [[curator]] for the [[Princeton University Library]], believes the paper is possibly from [[Venice]], Italy.<ref name="NJ" />
==Gallery== {{Gallery |title=Pages from the Cedid Atlas |File:Cedid Atlas (World) 1803.jpg |World map |File:Cedid Atlas (Middle East) 1803.jpg |The Ottoman controlled Middle East |File:Cedid Atlas (Greece and the Balkans) 1803.jpg |Balkans and Anatolia |File:Cedid Atlas (Europe) 1803.jpg |Europe, including Ottoman Southeast Europe |File:Cedid Atlas (Africa) 1803.jpg |Africa, including Ottoman North Africa |File:Cedid Atlas (Egypt) 1803.jpg |[[Ottoman Egypt]] }}
==Articles and papers== * [http://oi.uchicago.edu/pdf/oimp27.pdf University of Chicago - European Cartographers and the Ottoman World (1500-1750)] * [http://www.turkishculture.org/fine-art/graphic-arts/prints-graphic-arts-576.htm Turkish Cultural Foundation - Turkish Graphic Arts] * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/79494876/Jerusalem-Quarterly-Issue-48-Winter-2011 Jerusalem Quarterly - Shifting Ottoman Conceptions of Palestine : Ethnography and Cartography] * [http://www.iudergi.com/tr/index.php/tarih/article/viewFile/2242/1870 İstanbul Üniversitesi Dergisi - Article in Turkish by Cengiz Orhonlu]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{tr icon}} * [http://www.iudergi.com/tr/index.php/tarih/article/viewFile/16755/15942 İstanbul Üniversitesi Dergisi - Article in Turkish by Deniz Ekinci]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{tr icon}}
==Books== * ''The Ottoman Centuries: The Rise and Fall of the Turkish Empire''. Kinross, Patrick. Perennial, London, 1977. * ''İmparatorluğun En Uzun Yüzyılı''. Ortaylı, İlber. Hil Yayinları, İstanbul, 1983. {{tr icon}} * ''Military, Administrative, and Scholarly Maps and Plans''. Karamustafa, Ahmet T. In ''"The History of Cartography, Vol. 2, Book 1: Cartography in the Traditional Islamic and South Asian Societies, edited by J. B. Harley and David Woodward, pp. 209–28"'', University of Chicago Press, Chicago, 1992. * ''Türk Bilim ve Matbaacılık Tarihinde Mühendishane, Mühendishane Matbaası ve Kütüphanesi (1776-1826)''. Beydilli, Kemal. Eren Yayıncılık, İstanbul, 1995. {{tr icon}} * ''Mühendishane ve Üsküdar Matbaalarında Basılan Kitapların Listesi ve Bir Katolog''. Beydilli, Kemal. Eren Yayıncılık, İstanbul, 1997. {{tr icon}} * ''History of the Ottoman Empire, Volume 2''. Shaw, S.J. and Shaw, E.Z., Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1997. * ''Mahmud Raif Efendi ve Nizâm-ı Cedîd'e Dair Eseri''. Beydilli, Kemal & Şahin, İlhan. Türk Tarih Kurumu Yayınları, Ankara, 2001. {{tr icon}}

"New Order" Artifacts - ''Cedid Atlas Tercümesi''] * [http://www.lithuanianmaps.com/Maps1801-15.html Maps: 1801-1815] * [http://maviboncuk.blogspot.com/2006/09/ottoman-printed-world-map-in-mercators.html Cornucopia of Ottomania and Turcomania - Ottoman Printed World Map] * [http://www.sochistdisc.org/news_letter_May_2002/terra-cognita_7.htm Terra Cognita - Newsletter of the Society for the History of Discoveries - ''Cedid Atlas'' at the Newberry Library] * [http://goran.baarnhielm.net/Islam/eng/monter4.htm Turkish Incunabula in the Sweden Royal Library] * [http://goran.baarnhielm.net/Islam/eng/Cedid_Atlas.htm Sweden Royal Library - ''Cedid Atlas''] {{col-break}} * [http://catalogue.leidenuniv.nl/primo_library/libweb/action/dlSearch.do?dscnt=1&onCampus=false&search_scope=UBL_LMS&fromLogin=true&query=any%2Cexact%2CPPN236299727&dstmp=1343486765958&group=GUEST&vid=UBL_V1&institution=UBL&fromLogin=true Leiden University Library - revision.comment: Usual British usage: ".
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use British English|date=April 2017}} {{Redirect|Ceremony of the Keys|other uses|Ceremony of the Keys (Edinburgh)|and|Ceremony of the Keys (Gibraltar)}}
[[File:Entrance to 'Tower of London'.jpg|thumb|[[Yeomen Warders|Yeoman Warder]] with escort, [[Tower of London]]]] The '''Ceremony of the Keys''' is an ancient ritual, held every evening at the [[Tower of London]], when the main gates are locked for the night.<ref name="LondonEncylopaedia">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xa0D0PqiwfEC&pg=PA145&dq=%22Ceremony+of+the+Keys%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT4p3bzsbXAhWDC8AKHS8yA4o4HhDoAQhKMAY#v=onepage&q=%22Ceremony%20of%20the%20Keys%22&f=false |title=The London Encylopaedia |last=Weinreb |first=Ben |last2=Hibbert |first2=Christopher |last3=Keay |first3=Julia |last4=Keay |first4=John |publisher=MacMillan |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-4050-4924-5 |edition=3rd |publication-place=London |pages=145 |access-date=17 November 2017}}</ref> It is said to be the oldest military ceremony in the world,<ref name="Hogg">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ptNXAAAAYAAJ&q=%22Ceremony+of+the+Keys%22&dq=%22Ceremony+of+the+Keys%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiw0dmUzMbXAhWnL8AKHZ_mCxU4ChDoAQg4MAM |title=Customs and Traditions of England |last=Hogg |first=Garry |publisher=Arco Publishing Company |year=1971 |isbn=9780668024907 |pages=58 |access-date=17 November 2017}}</ref> and is the best-known ceremonial tradition of the Tower.<ref name="Brewer">{{Cite book |title=Brewer's Dictionary of London Phrase and Fable |last=Willey |first=Russ |publisher=Chambers Harrap |year=2009 |isbn=978 0550 104 458 |location=London}}</ref>
==The ceremony== At exactly 9.53 pm, the Chief [[Yeomen Warders|Yeoman Warder]], dressed in [[Tudor period|Tudor]] watchcoat and bonnet, and carrying a candle lantern, leaves the Byward Tower and falls in with the Escort to the Keys, a military escort made up of armed members of the [[Queen's Guard|Tower of London Guard]].<ref name="HouseholdDivision">{{Cite web |url=http://www.householddivision.org.uk/guard-at-the-tower-ceremony |title=Guard at the Tower |website=The Household Division |access-date=17 November 2017}}</ref> The Warder passes his lantern to a soldier, and marches with his escort to the outer gate. The sentries on duty salute the Queen’s Keys as they pass.<ref name="Changing-Guard">{{Cite web |url=https://changing-guard.com/ceremony-of-the-keys.html |title=Tower of London / Ceremony of the Keys |website=Changing-Guard.com |access-date=17 November 2017}}</ref>
The Warder first locks the outer gate and then the gates of the Middle and Byward Towers. The Warder and escort march down Water Lane, until they reach the Bloody Tower archway where a sentry challenges the party to identify themselves:<ref name="Changing-Guard"/>
:'''Sentry''': "Halt! Who comes there?" :'''Chief Warder''': "The keys". :'''Sentry''': "Whose keys?" :'''Chief Warder''': "[[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth's]] keys". :'''Sentry''': "Pass Queen Elizabeth's Keys. All's well".<ref name="Changing-Guard"/><ref>The precise wording of the challenge/response differs very slightly between sources</ref>
The Warder and escort march down to the foot of Broadwalk Steps where the main Tower Guard is drawn up to meet them. The party halts, and the officer in charge gives the command to [[Present arms (command)|present arms]]. The Chief Warder steps forward, doffs his bonnet, and proclaims:
:'''Chief Warder''': "God preserve Queen Elizabeth". :'''Guard''': "Amen!"<ref name="Changing-Guard"/><ref name="LondonEncylopaedia" />
On the answering “Amen” the clock of the Waterloo Barracks strikes 10pm and the [[Last Post]] is sounded, marking the end of the ceremony.<ref name="Changing-Guard"/><ref name="LondonEncylopaedia" />
The Guard is dismissed, and the Chief Warder takes the keys to the Queen's House for safekeeping overnight.<ref name="Changing-Guard"/>
==History== The origins of the ceremony are unknown. It may have begun during the Middle Ages,<ref name="LondonEncylopaedia" /> and it is often stated that a ceremony in some form has been held since the 14th century.<ref name="HRP">{{Cite web |url=https://www.hrp.org.uk/tower-of-london/explore/ceremony-of-the-keys/ |title=Ceremony of the Keys |website=Historic Royal Palaces |access-date=17 November 2017}} (''"700 year old ancient ceremony''")</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://changing-guard.com/ceremony-of-the-keys.html | title=Tower of London / Ceremony of the Keys | website=Changing-Guard.com | accessdate=17 November 2017}} ("''for about 700 years''")</ref> Written instructions that the keys should be placed in a safe place by a Tower officer, after securing the gates, date back to the 16th century.<ref name="LondonEncylopaedia" /> In its current form the ceremony is likely to date to the 19th century when the institution of the [[Yeomen Warders]] was reformed by the then Constable of the Tower, the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington]].<ref name="LondonEncylopaedia" />
The ceremony has never been cancelled, and has been delayed only on a single occasion due to enemy action during the [[World War II|Second World War]].<ref name="Changing-Guard"/><ref name="HouseholdDivision"/> During an [[airstrike|air raid]] on London, a number of incendiary bombs fell on the old Victorian guardroom just as the Chief Warder and the escort were coming through the Bloody Tower archway. The Chief Warder and the escort were blown off their feet, but they recovered and carried on. The Tower holds a letter from the Officer of the Guard apologising to [[George VI of the United Kingdom|King George VI]] that the ceremony was late, along with a reply from the King which says that the officer is not to be punished as the delay was due to enemy action.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}
==Access to the ceremony== Between 40 and 50 visitors are allowed access to the ceremony each night, under escort.<ref name="HouseholdDivision"/> Tickets are free but must be obtained in advance from [[Historic Royal Palaces]], the organisation that looks after the Tower.<ref name="HRP2">{{Cite web |url=https://www.hrp.org.uk/tower-of-london/explore/ceremony-of-the-keys |title=Ceremony of the Keys |website=Historic Royal Palaces |access-date=17 November 2017}}</ref> The event is usually sold out at least 12 months in advance.<ref name="HRP2"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web| url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UPPl6bFwHOg | title=Ceremony of the Keys at the Tower of London | website=[[YouTube]] | author=Hustyna | accessdate=17 November 2017}} * A 1936 BBC recording of the Tower of London ceremony: {{Cite web |url=http://www.soundsurvey.org.uk/index.php/survey/radio_recordings/1930s/1802/ |title=Ceremony of the Keys 1936 |website= London Sound Survey |access-date=13 November 2017}} * [http://www.trooping-the-colour.co.uk/keys Order of the Ceremony of The Keys (London)], a personal website describing the ceremony (with photographs)
[[Category:State ritual and ceremonies]] [[Category:14th-century establishments in Europe]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in the City of London]] [[Category:Events in London]] [[Category:Tower of London]] [[Category:Events in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Ceremonies in the United Kingdom]]

page.title: Comparison of Java and Android API

revision.text: This article compares the [[application programming interface]]s (APIs) and [[virtual machine]]s (VMs) of the programming language [[Java (programming language)|Java]] and operating system [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. While most Android applications are written in Java-like language, there are some differences between the Java API and the Android API, and Android does not run [[Java bytecode]] by a traditional [[Java virtual machine]] (JVM), but instead by a [[Dalvik (software)|Dalvik]] virtual machine in older versions of Android, and an [[Android Runtime]] (ART) in newer versions, that compile the same code that Dalvik runs to [[Executable and Linkable Format]] (ELF) executables containing [[machine code]]. Java bytecode in Java Archive ([[JAR (file format)|JAR]]) files is not executed by Android devices. Instead, Java classes are compiled into a proprietary bytecode format and run on [[Dalvik (software)|Dalvik]] (or compiled version thereof with newer ART), a specialized virtual machine (VM) designed for Android. Unlike Java VMs, which are [[stack machine]]s (stack-based architecture), the Dalvik VM is a [[register machine]] (register-based architecture). Dalvik has some traits that differentiate it from other standard VMs:{{cite web | url=http://blogs.sun.com/jrose/entry/with_android_and_dalvik_at | title=with Android and Dalvik at Google I/O | last=Rose|first=John | date=2008-05-31 | accessdate=2008-06-08}} * The VM was designed to use less space. * The [[Class (file format)#The constant pool|constant pool]] has been modified to use only [[32-bit]] indexes to simplify the [[Interpreter (computing)|interpreter]]. * Standard Java bytecode executes 8-bit stack instructions. Local variables must be copied to or from the operand stack by separate instructions. Dalvik instead uses its own 16-bit instruction set that works directly on local variables. The local variable is commonly picked by a 4-bit ''virtual register'' field. Because the bytecode loaded by the Dalvik virtual machine is not Java bytecode and due to the way Dalvik loads classes, it is impossible to load library packages as [[JAR (file format)|jar files]]. A different procedure must be used to load Android libraries, in which the content of the underlying dex file must be copied in the application private internal storage area before it is loaded.{{cite web | url=http://android-developers.blogspot.com/2011/07/custom-class-loading-in-dalvik.html | title=Custom Class Loading in Dalvik | publisher=[[Google]] | author=Fred Chung | date=2011-07-28 | accessdate=2011-11-27}} ==System properties== As is the case for the [[Java SE]] class {{Javadoc:SE|java/lang|System}}, the Android {{Javadoc:Android|java/lang|System}} class allows retrieving system properties. However, some mandatory properties defined with the Java virtual machine have no meaning or a different meaning on Android. For example: * java.version property returns 0 because it is not used on Android. * java.specification.version invariably returns 0.9 independently of the version of Android used. * java.class.version invariably returns 50 independently of the version of Android used. * user.dir has a different meaning on Android. * user.home and user.name properties do not exist on Android. ==Class library== Current versions of Android use the latest Java language and its libraries (but not full [[graphical user interface]] (GUI) frameworks), not the [[Apache Harmony]] Java implementation, that older versions used. [[Java 8]] source code that works in latest version of Android, can be made to work in older versions of Android. ===java.lang package=== By default, the default output stream {{Javadoc:Android|member=out|java/lang|System|out}} and {{Javadoc:Android|member=err|java/lang|System|err}} do not output anything,{{cite web | url=http://developer.android.com/guide/developing/tools/adb.html | title=Android Debug Bridge | quote=''By default, the Android system sends stdout and stderr (System.out and System.err) output to /dev/null.'' | publisher=[[Google]] | accessdate=2009-05-31}} and developers are encouraged to use the {{Javadoc:Android|android/util|Log}} class, which logs Strings on the LogCat tool.{{cite web | url=http://developer.android.com/guide/developing/debugging/debugging-log.html | title=Reading and Writing Logs | publisher=[[Google]] | accessdate=2011-11-27}} This has changed at least from [[Android Honeycomb|HoneyComb]], and they now output to the log console also. ===Graphics and widget library=== Android does not use the [[Abstract Window Toolkit]] nor the [[Swing (Java)|Swing]] library. [[User interface]]s are built using View objects. Android uses a framework similar to Swing, based on {{Javadoc:Android|android/view|View}}s rather than {{Javadoc:SE|javax/swing|JComponent}}s. However, Android widgets are not [[JavaBean]]s: the Android application {{Javadoc:Android|android/content|Context}} must be provided to the widget at creation. ====Look and feel==== Android widget library does not support a [[pluggable look and feel]] architecture. The look and feel of Android widgets must be embedded in the widgets. However, a limited ability exists to set styles and themes for an application.{{cite web | url=http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/themes.html#ApplyAStyle | title=Applying Styles and Themes | publisher=[[Google]] | accessdate=2011-09-03}} ====Layout manager==== Contrary to Swing where [[layout manager]]s can be applied to any [[Container (abstract data type)|container widget]], Android layout behavior is encoded in the containers.{{cite web | url=http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/layout-objects.html | title=Common Layout Objects | publisher=[[Google]] | accessdate=2011-09-03}} ===java.beans package=== Android includes only a small subset of the java.beans package ({{Javadoc:Android|java/beans|PropertyChangeEvent}} and related classes). ==See also== * [[Android (operating system)]] * [[Java (programming language)]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Android}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Java and Android API comparison}} [[Category:Android (operating system)]] [[Category:Java (programming language)|Android API comparison]] [[Category:Computing comparisons]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} '''Document Number Nine''' (or '''Document No. 9'''), more properly the '''Communiqué on the Current State of the Ideological Sphere'''<ref name=cf/> (also translated as the '''Briefing on the Current Situation in the Ideological Realm'''<ref name=econ1/>), is a [[Internal media of the People's Republic of China|confidential internal document]] widely circulated within the [[Communist Party of China]] in 2013 by the [[General Office of the Communist Party of China]].<ref>[http://www.hndj.gov.cn/html/jgdj/gzkx/2013/5168269.html 省储备局认真学习贯彻落实《关于当前意识形态领域情况的通报》] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615122048/http://www.hndj.gov.cn/html/jgdj/gzkx/2013/5168269.html |date=15 June 2013 }}，湖南机关党建, 16 May 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.vtibet.cn/zhuanti/2013-05/09/cms340592article.shtml 西藏广电局召开传达学习有关文件精神会议] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615105337/http://www.vtibet.cn/zhuanti/2013-05/09/cms340592article.shtml |date=15 June 2013 }}，中国西藏之声网, 9 May 2013</ref> The document was first ciculated in July 2012.<ref>[http://theory.people.com.cn/n/2012/0703/c83855-18430666.html 任洁，当前我国意识形态建设面临的六大挑战，党建2012–第7期]</ref> The document warns of seven dangerous Western values, allegedly including media freedom and judicial independence. Teaching on any of the seven topics is forbidden.<ref name=SCMP82913>{{cite news|title=Seven subjects off limits for teaching, Chinese universities told: Civil rights, press freedom and party's mistakes among subjects banned from teaching in order described by an academic as back-pedalling|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1234453/seven-subjects-limits-teaching-chinese-universities-told|accessdate=19 September 2013|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=29 August 2013|author=Raymond Li}}</ref> There is an emphasis on controlling and preventing communication using the internet of ideas subversive to one party rule. The document was issued in the context of planned economic reforms and increased calls for political reform.<ref name = "NYT51313" >[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/14/world/asia/chinese-leaders-warn-of-dangerous-western-values.html "China Warns Officials Against ‘Dangerous’ Western Values"] article by Chris Buckley in ''[[The New York Times]]'' 13 May 2013</ref> It has been described as a critique of the "liberal ways of thinking".<ref>{{cite news|title=Mixed messages|url=https://www.economist.com/news/china/21580195-xi-jinping-signals-left-while-turning-right-or-it-other-way-round-mixed-messages|newspaper=The Economist|date= 29 June 2013|issn=0013-0613|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref>
The document was not made available to public by the Chinese government, but in July 2013 was allegedly leaked by Chinese dissident journalist [[Gao Yu (journalist)|Gao Yu]], who was in turn sentenced to a seven-year imprisonment for "leaking state secrets".<ref>{{cite web|title=Chinese journalist Gao Yu faces seven years in prison for 'leaking state secrets'|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/china-journalist-gao-yu-prison-sentence-leaking-state-secrets/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Chris|last1=Buckley|title=Chinese Journalist Sentenced to 7 Years on Charges of Leaking State Secrets|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/17/world/asia/china-journalist-gao-yu-gets-7-year-sentence.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=16 April 2015|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref>
It is unclear whether this document is official Chinese policy or just a faction within the government.<ref name=cw7/> However, ''The New York Times'' suggests that it "bears the unmistakable imprimatur of [[Xi Jinping]]". <ref name=nyt2> {{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/20/world/asia/chinas-new-leadership-takes-hard-line-in-secret-memo.html?mcubz=1 | title=China Takes Aim at Western Ideas |work=The New York Times}}</ref> It is thought that Document No. 9 was issued by the Central Committee General Office, and would have required the approval of Mr. Xi and other top leaders.<ref name=nyt2/> A harsh crackdown against human rights lawyers, media outlets, academics, and other such independent thinkers has followed the document's publication.<ref name=cw7/>
==Name== The document has been described as a [[communiqué]]<ref name=cf>{{cite web|title=Document 9: A ChinaFile Translation|url=http://www.chinafile.com/document-9-chinafile-translation|website=ChinaFile|date=8 November 2013|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref> or [[Flyer (pamphlet)|circular]].<ref name=econ1>{{cite news|title=Tilting backwards|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/analects/2013/06/political-rebalancing|newspaper=The Economist|date=24 June 2013|issn=0013-0613|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref> The name of the document (''Document Number Nine''), as it came to be commonly referred in Western English-language press,<ref name=econ1/><ref name=nyt>{{cite news|first1=Chris|last1=Buckley|title=China Takes Aim at Western Ideas|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/20/world/asia/chinas-new-leadership-takes-hard-line-in-secret-memo.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=19 August 2013|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref> comes from the fact that it was the ninth such document issued that year in China.<ref name=cf/>
==Contents== The document is highly critical of what can be broadly described as "[[Western philosophy|Western values]]" (the document itself uses terms such as "Western values", "Western principles", "Western standards", "Western ideas", and more precisely, "Western constitutional democracy" and "Western-style theories of governance", as well as making references to "Western anti-China forces").<ref name=cf/> The document is critical of "extremely malicious" ideals spreading in the [[Chinese society]], such as ideas of (Western) [[constitutional democracy]], [[civil society]], [[universal values]] ([[freedom]], democracy, and human rights), [[neo-liberalism]], and [[freedom of the press]] (described as the "Western news values").<ref name=cf/><ref name=econ1/><ref name=nyt/> The document warns that such subjects undermine the [[Chinese Communist Party]]'s control over the Chinese society.<ref name=econ1/> The document also promotes ways of dealing with these problems, which include "Unwavering adherence to the principle of the Party's control of media."
===The Seven Noteworthy Problems=== The document specifically addresses the following issues that were seen as problems.<ref name=cw7>{{cite web | title=Document 9 |url= http://www.chinafile.com/document-9-chinafile-translation}}</ref> These are the terms used in the document itself: # Promoting Western Constitutional Democracy: An attempt to undermine the current leadership and the "socialism with Chinese characteristics" system of governance. (Including ''the separation of powers, the multi-party system, general elections, and independent judiciaries''.) # Promoting “universal values” in an attempt to weaken the theoretical foundations of the Party’s leadership. (That ''“the West’s values are the prevailing norm for all human civilization”, that “only when China accepts Western values will it have a future”''.) # Promoting civil society in an attempt to dismantle the ruling party’s social foundation. (i.e. that ''individual rights are paramount and ought to be immune to obstruction by the state''.) # Promoting Neoliberalism, attempting to change China’s Basic Economic System. (i.e. ''unrestrained economic liberalization, complete privatization, and total marketization''.) # Promoting the West’s idea of journalism, challenging China’s principle that the media and publishing system should be subject to Party discipline. # Promoting historical nihilism, trying to undermine the history of the CCP and of New China. (For example ''to deny the scientific and guiding value of Mao Zedong thought''.) # Questioning Reform and Opening and the socialist nature of socialism with Chinese characteristics. (For example, saying ''“We have deviated from our Socialist orientation.”'')
==Leak== The contents of the memo became known when accounts of presenting it to cadre in the [[Liaoyuan]] municipal government were published in the local paper.<ref>[http://www.mzyfz.com/cms/shishiyaowen/jishiyaowen/xinwenkuaixun/html/715/2013-05-13/content-748603.html 市委组织部迅速贯彻落实《关于当前意识形态领域情况的通报》及《吉林：创新领航催振兴》通讯精神]，''Liaoyuan Daily'', 10 May 2013</ref><ref>[http://epaper.cnwest.com/xyrb/html/2013-05/21/content_4786102.htm 市委召开常委（扩大）会议 专题学习当前意识形态领域情况通报]，''Xianyang Daily'', 21 May 2013，See also：[http://www.xianyang.gov.cn/dwgk/2013/0521/76801.html]</ref> In May 2013 cadre at the [[Chongqing]] Party Committee for Urban and Rural Construction studied the material,<ref>[http://www.ccc.gov.cn/xygl/djgz/djzx/2013-05-09-2909359.html 高举旗帜坚定信心 坚决同党中央保持高度一致]，重庆市城乡建设委员会, 9 May 2013，See also：[http://news.stnn.cc/china/201305/t20130513_1891025.html]</ref> as did cadre in [[Anyang]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150723062123/http://news.takungpao.com/mainland/focus/2013-05/1605728.html 安阳政协学习《当前意识形态领域情况的通报》的通知], ''Ta Kung Pao'', 13 May 2013. archived from [http://News.Takungpao.Com/mainland/focus/2013-05/1605728.Html the original] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723062123/http://news.takungpao.com/mainland/focus/2013-05/1605728.Html |date=23 July 2015 }} on 23 July 2015</ref> However, there were no explicit mentions of the seven Western values above.
In April 2015, the ''Wall Street Journal's'' Josh Chin<ref>https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-sentences-71-year-old-journalist-to-jail-1429254633</ref> reported a 71-year-old Chinese journalist was convicted for releasing Document 9. Journalist Gao Yu was sentenced to seven years in prison by Beijing's Third Intermediate People’s Court after being found guilty in a closed trial of leaking state secrets to foreign media. Ms Gao was accused by the court of leaking an internal Communist Party directive to an overseas Chinese news site in 2013, according to her lawyer, Mo Shaoping. Known as Document No. 9. Historically, it is rare for Chinese authorities to detain or jail elderly critics, who were traditionally given quiet warnings when they crossed political red lines. The article suggests that the charge is a pretext for aggressive action against political dissent and cites other examples of elderly publishers and journalists being prosecuted.
==Analysis== According to news analysis by a reporter at ''[[The New York Times]]'', the emphasis on political discipline is intended to forestall leftist, or Maoist, opposition to needed economic reforms avoiding the split which resulted in the Soviet Union during Gorbachev's reform efforts when media freedom resulted in publishing of a great deal of critical historical material and alienation of the mass of party workers.<ref name = "NYT51313" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web|title=The political economy of Document Number Nine|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2013/08/20/the-political-economy-of-document-number-nine/|work=Foreign Policy|date=20 August 2013|accessdate=6 May 2015}}
[[Category:2013 in China]] [[Category:2013 documents]] [[Category:Classified documents]] [[Category:Xi Jinping]]

{{italic title}} The '''''Encyclopedia of Vernacular Architecture of the World''''' is a three-volume [[encyclopedia]] detailing the [[vernacular architecture|traditional architecture]] of the world, by cultural region. Published in 1997, it was edited by [[Paul Oliver]] of the [[Oxford Institute for Sustainable Development]] and [[Oxford Brookes University]].
The work was initially published by the [[Cambridge University Press]] in three volumes, totalling 2,500 pages. According to its website, "The first of the three volumes focuses on the [[architectural theory|theories]], [[principles of architecture|principles]] and [[architectural philosophy|philosophy]] that underpin traditional architecture. Volumes 2 and 3 consider these principles within specific cultural and societal contexts."
As of 2012 his encyclopedia is out of print and generally unavailable. Copies available on the internet range from $2,500 to over $5,000 (U.S.D)
The encyclopedia includes a [[glossary]], [[lexicon]] and [[bibliography]] and most styles described are also illustrated.
The companion volume ''[[Atlas of Vernacular Architecture of the World]]'' is published by Routledge. [http://www.routledge.com/9780415411516] [https://web.archive.org/web/20070223164530/http://www.brookes.ac.uk/schools/be/oisd/act/ivau/index.html]
==References== *[[Cambridge University Press]], ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20160407034928/http://www.cambridge.org/uk/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521564229 Encyclopedia of Vernacular Architecture of the World]'' *[[Routledge]], ''[http://www.routledgearchitecture.com Routledge Architecture Arena]'' {{Authority control}} [[Category:1997 books]] [[Category:Architecture books]] [[Category:Indigenous architecture]] [[Category:Specialized encyclopedias|Vernacular architecture]] [[Category:Vernacular architecture]]
{{architecture-book-stub}} {{encyclopedia-stub}}

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Fauna Entomologica Scandinavica''}} '''''Fauna Entomologica Scandinavica''''' is a scientific book series of [[entomology|entomological]] identification manuals for [[insect]]s (and other terrestrial [[arthropod]]s) in North-West Europe, mainly [[Fennoscandia]] and [[Denmark]]. The series is used by a number of groups, such as ecologists, biologists, and insect collectors. The books are in English, and published by the Dutch academic publishing house [[Brill Publishers|Brill]].
